messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Botan and shishi
messages.msgSnippet: Mike - I ve also read somewhere (Joly s?) about some princess (or queen?) was for some reason transformed into a shishi and that the peony was her favorite
messages.messageBody:
Mike -

I've also read somewhere (Joly's?) about some princess (or queen?) was for some reason transformed into a shishi and that the peony was her favorite food, thus the association. It is a wonderful motif and I have a number of very nice shakudo and shakudo/gold menuki depicting shishi and peony.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Mike M. Yamaguchi
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, July 03, 2003 10:23 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Botan and shishi



>I have seen the botan (peony) paired many times with a shishi on
>tsuba and fuchi/kashira.
>
>I was wondering, what is the connection between the two/what is the
>theme?


The shishi is considered the king of all animals, and the botan is
considered the king (if not the queen) of all flowers. The pair symbolizes
the best/strongest. The pairing of lion and peony is a Chinese concept,
and the design is still seen today among Chinese works of art/craft. The
peony was brought to Japan from Tang China as medicine, and the flower
became popular among Heian court nobles. Stylized botan flower became
popular design motif, including the "mon" crest, by the Kamakura period. A
branch of the Genji clan in Settsu Province used a "mon" showing shishi and
botan around that period (ca. 1300), so the pairing has been in Japan for
some time.

The botan/shishi pair was (still is?) also a popular irezumi (tattoo) motif
among the yakuza (gangsters).


Best,

Mike Yamaguchi

Yahoo! Groups Sponsor

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Botan and shishi
messages.msgSnippet: Hello, first of all I would like to thank everyone for participating is this most interesting thread. I do have a (silly) question though, I thought that the
messages.messageBody:
Hello, first of all I would like to thank everyone for participating is
this most interesting thread. I do have a (silly) question though, I
thought that the Dragon was King of all animals, like in China where it
symbolizes the Emperor among other things. If this is not the case in
Japan, could someone please explain the meaning of the Dragon in
Japanese art ?

Also in China there are a number of myth. beasts that are "children of
the dragon", is this the case in Japan also ?

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Mike M. Yamaguchi [mailto:mmyamaguchi@...]
Verzonden: donderdag 3 juli 2003 17:23
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com

symbolizes
the best/strongest. The pairing of lion and peony is a Chinese concept,
and the design is still seen today among Chinese works of art/craft.
The
peony was brought to Japan from Tang China as medicine, and the flower
became popular among Heian court nobles. Stylized botan flower became
popular design motif, including the "mon" crest, by the Kamakura period.
A
branch of the Genji clan in Settsu Province used a "mon" showing shishi
and
botan around that period (ca. 1300), so the pairing has been in Japan

some time.

Best,

Mike Yamaguchi

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Botan and shishi
messages.msgSnippet: Apart from religious association, Shishi are shown in the vicinity of waterfalls, and amid rocks outof which grow peonies, the King of Beasts with the King of
messages.messageBody:
"Apart from religious association, Shishi are shown in
the vicinity of waterfalls, and amid rocks outof which
grow peonies, the King of Beasts with the King of
Flowers in poetical conjunction."

William H. Edmunds

-Pointers and Clues to the subject of Chinese and
Japanese Art- p.572

(Not much- but its a start.)

messages.messageBody:
Gentlemen:

I have seen the botan (peony) paired many times with a shishi on
tsuba and fuchi/kashira.

I was wondering, what is the connection between the two/what is the
theme?

Thanks,
Ron P.
